indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Availability of information on HIV and AIDS spending. - Level of mainstreaming of HIV and gender issues in development policies, programmes and plans - Existence of adequate capacity of umbrella organisations to coordinate HIV responses. - Existence of human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Existence of evidence to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response

baseline.comment: - No information on actual spending on HIV and AIDS - Limited mainstreaming of HIV and gender issues in development policies, programmes and plans - Inadequate capacity of umbrella organisations to coordinate HIV responses. - Inadequate capacity of the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Unsustainable financing mechanisms for the HIV response

target.comment: -Information on HIV and AIDS spending availed e.g National AIDS accountability Score card institutionalized - HIV and gender issues mainstreamed in development policies, programmes and plans. Specfically: 1. An HIV committee established in Kampala city authority 2- Increased number of top political and urban leaders committed to the National HIV response 3- Non communicable disease health clubs established among university students 4- Increase in the number of newspaper publications on Non communicable diseases and tobacco control 5- At least 15 women and girls living with and orphaned with HIV supported in 2 districts to regain access to property and land 6- Advocacy for removal of clauses that impact on HIV regression in the HIV Prevention and Management bill 7- Advocacy with law makers and policy makers on the need to manage the impact of the Anti homosexuality Act - Adequate capacity of umbrella organisations in place to coordinate HIV responses. e.g Supporting Uganda AIDS Commission to engender the National HIV Strategic Plan and the Global fund process -Availability of Human resources in the UN Joint Team on AIDS to coordinate the HIV response - Evidence in place to inform sustainable financing mechanisms / options for the HIV response

actual.comment:
-Availability of information on HIV and AIDS spending. National Aids accountability score card was launched, disseminated and institutionalized in 7 districts, as a result there is increased accountability of health services in certain health centers like Mwiizi health center 4 where the government vehicle was brought back due to the community demand . -HIV and gender issues have been to some extent mainstreamed in development policies, programmes and plans. Specifically: 1- An HIV committee was institutionalized at Kampala City authority which has facilitated the organization of the elimination of mother to child transmission campaign in Kampala district 2- Increased commitment of political leaders in addressing the HIV response which has contributed to decline in the number of new infections from 140,000 to 120,000 and also lead to the reduction mother to child transmission rates from 21000 to 8000 new infections ( Country Progress report) 3- Urban leaders currently integrating gender and HIV in their urban programs and plans as a result there is increased commitment of urban leaders in mobilizing their communities to access HIV prevention, care and treatment services 4 - Two non communicable disease health clubs have been established in Mukono and Kampala University 5 - One way SMS platform has been develop to sensitize the youth about the dangers of smoking and related non communicable diseases. 6- Eleven women and 7 girls living with and affected with HIV have been supported to regain access to their property and land , as a result 2 girls that had dropped out school have bounced back to school.
7- As a result of the gender and HIV integration study conducted last year, gender and HIV training have been conducted for the local government sectors leading to the increase in gender informed budgets and work plans submitted to the ministry of local government; 8.An HIV and the law dialogue was conducted in an effort to sensitize policy makers,

target.comment: i. Conduct 1 Urban Leaders AIDS Forum ii.Review 3 AMICAAL policies iii.240 students sensitized and capacities built to do peer education on HIV and NCDs prevention iv. 1 documentary for TV mentions for 2 months about health service delivery from rural health centres v.Provide legal aid to 60 clients

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Thematic working group on GHG inventory system and national dialogue platforms and coordination mechanisms established. 2. Number of Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMA) full proposals in place. 3. MRV for GHG inventory systems and NAMAs in place.

baseline.comment: 1. There are no thematic working groups and dialogue platforms on GHG inventory systems in place. 2. There is no systematic Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) development full proposal yet. 3. There is no MRV for GHG Inventory system and NAMA in place.

target.comment: 1. Thematic Working Group on GHG Inventory established and Sources of available data in key source categories identified. 2. Two NAMA full proposals prepared. 3. MRV systems designed to support implementation and evaluation of NAMAs.

actual.comment: 1. Thematic working groups on Greenhouse Gas inventory created and capacity developed. A study was also completed on institutional and data collecting arrangements that identified the available data in the key sectors. Furthermore a Greenhouse Gas Manual was developed to guide the UNDP facilitated Greenhouse Gas Unit under the Climate Change department to support the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory system. 2. Two Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMA) were developed. One NAMA concept has received funds from GEF to be fully implemented and another NAMA concept to be funded by the Low Emission Capacity Building global unit. 3. Measuring, Reporting and verification (MRV) systems/ framework is still under formulation.

target.comment: -A long term green house gas (GHG) inventory strategy in place -An institutionalized data collection system in place spearheaded by the GHG inventory unit -A sustainable and institutionalized QA/QC system in place -Capacities built within government for GHG inventory management -GHG inventory adopted and institutionalized for periodic inventorying and NCs - Rules of procedure detailed as part of a GHG inventory and NCs manual (timelines, budget -Business models develop for at least four NAMAs

actual.comment: - The National Inventory Strategy was finalized - The institutionalization of the data collection system is partially in place. Activities to complete this process are scheduled for early 2016. - The QA/QC framework is in place and outlined in the strategy. Capacity building is on-going to allow for a fully institutionalized and government owned QA/QC system - The GHG unit is operational and capacity is in place to manage the inventory - The GHG unit and the working groups established will constitute the backbone in the upcoming Third National Communication work. - Rules of procedures are part of the GHG inventory strategy - A consortium has been recruited to develop Business models for the four NAMAs and are expected to finalize the assignment is April 2016

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Uganda Diaspora Information Portal in place 2. Diaspora service department and key missions/desks on Diaspora fully connected. 3. Diaspora paper and policy providing policy framework for engaging internally and externally on Diaspora issues developed 4. Institutional arrangements for research and development in diplomacy and strategic studies strengthened. 5. International bonds - Feasibility established and internationalized i.e number of prints&electronic media and websites, increased Diaspora investments

baseline.comment: 1. Information protocol/system not in place for greater coordination and strategic partnerships with the diaspora i.e No database on expertise and skills of Diaspora in place, No VOIP system in place. 2. No Diaspora Policy and paper in place 3. No Government recognized specialized institute in country on diplomacy and strategic studies

target.comment: 1.Enhanced MoFAs Website/ Information portal/system functional in at least ten missions abroad. 2.A technical Paper/ Historical Assessment Report to be printed and launched. 3. Publish a book : Uganda and the World:

actual.comment: 1. The enhanced MoFAs Website has greatly improved information accessibility, coordination and strategic partnerships with the Diaspora. Ugandans in the Diaspora can now interact with MoFA officials through the MoFA Social Media network. 2. A technical Paper to highlight issues from the draft Diaspora Policy was done. And the issues were incorporated in the draft policy which is before cabinet for consideration. 3. The Book Uganda and the World: Half a Century of Foreign Policy 1962-2012 informs people about Ugandas ever growing relationship with the rest of the World and its peacefulness, development and economic potential

target.comment: -Institutional arrangements for research and development in diplomacy and strategic studies strengthened - Updated website/documentary in place - Support developnet of drafting 2 foreign policy bills

actual.comment: 1. From the roundtable workshop with donors, China pledged to construct the Institute, while South Korea and Norway promised to help at a later stage with capacity building programmes. 2. From the video documentary, Ugandans in the Diaspora are inspired to come and invest back at home in the areas of education, hotel and hospitality, health as well as manufacturing and trade. They are now aware of government programmes like National Registration of IDs 3. The process of drafting of the two bills Foreign Service bill and Uganda Institute for Diplomacy and International Affairs bills commenced. These two bills are critical because they will not only help build capacity of our Foreign Service but impact on Ugandas relations with the rest of the world

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
i.Revised harmonised regulatory framework for LG planning and budgeting in place. ii. Harmonised Acts in place (i.e Local Government Act, NPA Act and Budget Act)
iii.Selected districts and municipalities equipped with ICT to carry out effective planning and budgeting.
iv. Number of LGs trained on PPP policy and guidelines and are utilizing PPP approach in LG service delivery.

baseline.comment:
i.Weak and inconsistent legal, regulatory and coordination framework for service delivery i.e. Inconsistencies in mechanism for creation of districts and gaps in staffing structure.
ii.Legal, regulatory and coordination frameworks i.e. LG Act, NPA Act and budget Act are not harmonised for effective service delivery.
iii.Inadequate capacity (soft and hard ware) by LGs to deliver services.
iv.Public Private Partnership framework, not available at the LG level to inform service delivery.

target.comment:
i. Revised harmonised Local Government Planning and budgeting guidelines and training manual completed. ii.Disseminate and train 20 Local Governments on Public Private Policy Guidelines
iii.Equip 33 districts and 9 newly created municipalities with ICT equipments (GPSs) and have officers trained on its use. iv.Carry out dissemination and training of 20 Local Governments on Public Private Partnerships policy guidelines.

actual.comment: i. The revised harmonised Local Government (LGs)Planning and Budgeting Guidelines and Training manual Have been completed and are in place, being used by all Local Governments. ii. Dissemination and training of 24 Local Governments on Public Private Policy Guidelines againgst the target of 20 Local governments (LGs) have been completed. This has led to identification of additional sources of funding for example partnering with the private sector to provide health and education services in Local Governments other than relying on Central Government transfers and conditional grants. iii. Forty two Local governments (33 districts and 9) newly created municipalities were equipped with ICT equipments (GPSs) and have officers trained on its use. iv. 24 LGs were trained on Public Private Partnerships policy guidelines

target.comment: i. Installation and training of LG officers on use of Global Positioning Systems equipment in 15 LGs. ii. LG women leadership forum established in 6 LGs iii. 19 generic Training Materials revised to address policy and structural changes such as local economic development, community driven development, climate change, private sector financing, peace building etc. iv. Public Private Partnerships (PPP) policy framework disseminated in 20 LGs

actual.comment: i. Global Positioning Systems equipment installed and LG officers trained in 15 LGs ii. LG Women Leadership forum established in 5 LGs iii. 27 Generic Training Materials were revised to address policy and structural changes such as local economic development, community driven development, climate change, private sector financing, peace building, target surpassed. iv. PPP Policy framework disseminated in 24 LGs, target surpassed.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: i.Number of service delivery standards for sectors in place. ii.A functional platform linking national oversight entities (Parliament, IGG, Office of the Auditor General etc.) iii.Mechanism for empowering the public to demand for oversight services in place. iv.Number of selected recommendations arising from the capacity needs assessment for Parliament, NPA and UNNGOF implemented

baseline.comment: i.Weak capacity for inspection, monitoring and reporting on service delivery, characterized by absence service delivery standards. ii.Weak capacity for oversight monitoring and reporting on service delivery, characterized by lack of linkages among oversight entities iii.Inadequate public participation in the demand for accountability for effective service delivery.

target.comment: i.Harmonised guidelines highlighting indicators for NDP progress assessment reporting at MDA and LG level completed. ii.Service delivery standards for 6 sectors completed (Health, Roads, Environment, Physical Planning, Education and Housing). iii.One joint workshop for national oversight entities including Parliament, conducted to facilitate collaboration between the oversight entities. iv. Conduct feasibility study on strengthening the oversight functions; 4 selected recommendations arising from the capacity needs assessment for Parliament, National Planning Authority (NPA) etc implemented i.e. Feasibility study, on strengthening the oversight functions through parliamentary-public interface completed. 5 regional Capacity building trainings for CSOs on their oversight function conducted. Conduct a survey on the citizens views on vision 2040. 2 Learning and reflection platforms conducted on social accountability.

actual.comment:
i.Harmonised guidelines highlighting indicators for NDP progress assessment reporting at MDA and LG level has been completed.
ii.Service delivery standards for 6 sectors completed (Health, Roads, Environment, Physical Planning, Education and Housing).
iii. 2 regional Preparatory meetings on the Citizens survey on Uganda Vision 2040 was conducted in Lira and at National level in Kampala. These brought together over 120 participants including the district technical and political personnel and researchers. All together 5 preparatory workshops with an outreach of 220 citizens was completed.
iv. Feasibility study, on strengthening the oversight functions through parliamentary-public interface has been undertaken a final report is being considered by Parliament.
v. Five Capacity building trainings for CSOs on their oversight function completed and have informed programming
Specifically, A national Training of Trainers workshop for 40 community oversight facilitators and 4 advocacy officers was completed. Training was offered to enhance skills in advocacy, community facilitation, importance of oversight function, citizens role and mandate for oversight and linkages with the supply side of oversights i.e. the role of parliament.
The survey on the citizens views on vision 2040 is ongoing. It is envisaged to be finalised by September 2014. A bi-annual learning event on the theme the role of media in enhancing social accountability was conducted. CSOs were equipped with media relations skills and devised practical strategies for working with the media.

target.comment:
i.National Oversight report on the NDP completed.
ii.Service delivery standards for 2 sectors completed (Physical planning, Housing)
iii.Technical feasibility study on parliamentary radio and television completed
iv.2 capacity development fora between Parliaments Accountability Committees and District PACs conducted.
v.Parliamentary advocacy forums conducted on constitutional and electoral reform proposal
vi.Vision 2040 survey completed and report disseminated at the national level and in 5 regions
vii.4 Learnings/reflections on Social Accountability completed (covering national and sub-regional levels)
viii.Issues paper on CSO perspectives on strengthening their oversight functions prepared.

actual.comment:
i. National Oversight report (2013/2014) has been completed, awaiting board approval prior to printing.
ii. Draft Service delivery standards for the sectors of Physical Planning and Housing have been completed - awaiting consideration and approval at parliamentary level.
iii. 2 Interface training forums between Local Governments Accounts Committee and District Public Accounts were conducted bringing together 8 districts in Kabuli and 8 Districts in So roti. The District Public Accountability committees were trained on how to review and consider the Auditors General report for Lower Local Governments and hence forth parliament will no longer consider these reports but will rely on the opinion of District Accountability Committees.
iv. The Committee on legal and Parliamentary affairs was support to undertake consultations across the country on constitutional and electoral reform proposals.
v. The Vision 2040 survey was finalized, launched and 5 regional dissemination meetings held in Arua,Kabarole, Mbarara, Jinja and Lira; reaching out to over 473 stakeholders from Civil Society, Academia, Media, Politicians, Religious leaders and Local government officials. Over 1000 copies of the survey report were disseminated.
vi. 5 Learning and reflection meetings on social accountability were held in Kigezi region - Kabale, Lira, Mbale and Luwero for the central region, with an outreach of 266 CSOs and local government actors.
vii. A tool was administered to over 200 CSOs and select local government actors across the country to capture CSO perspectives on strengthening their oversight function. Data entry and analysis is ongoing, that will inform the synthesized issues paper on CSOs perspectives on strengthening their contribution to oversight.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. No. of contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. No. of Memorandum of understanding signed 3. No. of MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. No of tourism support institutions strengthened

baseline.comment: Tourism has a high potential for income generation and has been identified as one of the priority sectors by Government. However, the tourism sector is still underdeveloped, with a weak policy and regulatory framework; limited access to markets; limited product scope, weak business and technical skills; weak value chains. The following was the project baseline status: 1. Zero contracts between micro & small enterprises (MSMEs) and Large Tourism Operators & Enterprises signed and operational 2. Zero Memorandum of understanding signed 3. Zero MSME's in tourism strengthened 4. Zero tourism support institutions strengthened

target.comment:
Target 1
30 business linkages in selected tourism product value chains developed and operationalised
Target 2
6 Innovative Pro-poor Tourism Business Models developed and operationalised
Target 3
Capacity of 30 MSMEs in selected tourism product value chains strengthened to increase productivity and competitiveness
Target 4
Capacity of three selected Tourism Business Support Associations and institutions strengthened in service delivery and membership development.

actual.comment:
Target 1
As at end of June, 2014, 17 business linkages in selected tourism product value chains had been established; and 10 letters of establishment signed.
Target 2
7 case studies to elaborate the pro-poor, innovative tourism business models into the defined categories and 6 Tourism Business Models have been prepared. Further, the business development needs of the entities in the models have been identified. This will support the development of interventions to strengthen the pro-poor, innovative tourism business models.
Target 3
18 MSMEs strengthened. Specifically:
- 73 members of executive committees from 6 tourism Business Support Associations (BSAs) were emparted with knowledge and skills in Strategic Planning and Business Management of Tourism business associations and institutions
- 94 members of executive committees from 6 tourism BSAs were emparted with knowledge and skills in growing membership bases, improving customer care and service; and management of consumer markets
- 32 members of executive committees of 6 tourism BSAs were emparted with knowledge and skills in lobbying and advocacy
Target 4
Not yet started.

target.comment:
Target 1
12 business linkages operationalised
Target 2
Productive and entrepreneurial capacity of the 15 MSMEs involved in the Business Linkages strengthened
Target 3
Capacity of 3 selected tourism business support institutions strengthened.

actual.comment:
Target 1
12 business linkages between key market off-takers and MSMEs were strengthened, which has resulted in increased access to markets by the small enterprises (MSMEs), as well as growth of their businesses.
Target 2 The productive and entrepreneurial capacities of the 15 MSMEs involved in the business linkages has been strengthened through extensive trainings. As a result of the knowledge and skills gained, the MSMEs have been able to access new domestic and foreign markets thus creating opportunities to innovate, upgrade and increase their competitiveness.
Target 3
The capacity of three tourism business support associations and two tourism support institutions was strengthened in areas of quality assurance, research and evidence-based planning; development and implementation of sustainable marketing and branding strategies as well as development of their 5 year Strategic Plans.

baseline.comment: Agriculture contributes up to 23.6% of GDP while employing 83% of women (who contribute to 70-75% of agricultural production), and 71% of the men. More than 80% of the total agricultural output is produced through small-holder farms. However, the sector faces significant challenges - including low production volumes and inconsistent levels of supply, inadequate extension and business support services, limited market access and weak market chains.

target.comment:
Target 1
20 business linkages in Rice, Cassava and Beans Value Chains established
Target 2
13 business supoort associations (BSAs) strengthened
Target 3
5 pro-poor business models in agriculture sector designed and implemented
Target 4
200 MSMEs facilitated access to productive assets

actual.comment:
Target 1
(50) MoUs were signed between market off-takers and MSMEs. Among them, (31) have moved on to the next step in signing supply contracts.
Target 2
(13) business support associations have been receiving capacity building support including, strategic planning, governance, group formation, and production and marketing management.
Target 3
(10) pro-poor business models were developed and among them, (4) models were approved by the Technical Advisory Committee and ready for implementation.
Target 4
(600) MSMEs have been facilitated to access productive assets such as appropriate technologies, quality inputs, financial services, and market information.

target.comment: 1) 20 business linkages operationalized 2) 6 exchange visits conducted 3) 1 Innovative pro-poor business operationalized 4) 200 MSMEs facilitated access to productive assets

1) 4 business linkages established and have resulted 2,000 metric tons of commodities traded. 2) 3 exchange visits conducted 3) 1 innovative pro-poor business established 4) 90 MSMEs received capacity building interventions such as strategic planning, legal functionality, operational procedures and member mobilization.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Diagnostic study report on the review of the National Environment Management Policy (NEMP), related policies, laws and strategies in place. 2. Draft Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) sectoral guidelines for the energy, agriculture and, mining in place. 3. Strategy for management of Electronic waste in place. 4. Draft national biomass energy strategy in place. 5.1 National institutional capacity needs assessment report for Climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management. 5.2 Training manual for climate risk management in place and selected government officials trained in Climate risk management.

baseline.comment: 1. The National Environment Management Policy (1994) is in place but not reviewed or updated to cater for emerging environmental challenges. 2. The National Environmental Impact Assessment Regulations are in place but no EIA sectoral guidelines (for agriculture, mining, energy and other key sectors). 3. There is an electronic waste management policy but no strategy for management of electronic waste in place. 4. No national biomass energy strategy in place. 5.1 There is a National Disaster Preparedness and Management Policy and platform in place but there is an inadequate capacity for coordination of Climate risk management. 5.2 Most relevant government officials are inadequately skilled in climate risk management.

target.comment: 1. Draft National Environment Management Framework Policy in place. State of Environment Report in place. 2. Final Environment Impact Assessment guidelines for Agriculture, Mining, Energy and Fisheries sectors in place. Environment Natural Resources (ENR) gender strategy in place. Draft Wetlands Atlas in place. Baseline data sets for ENR Performance Measurement Framework in place. Draft Environment and natural resources gender strategy produced. ENR data collection tool in place. 3. Electronic waste strategy in place. 4. Biomass Energy Strategy in place. 5. Training manual on Climate Risk Management in place. Coordination Strategy for Climate Risk Management in place

actual.comment: 1. A final draft National state of environment report (NSOER) in place. 2. A final Environment Impact Assessment guidelines for Agriculture, Mining, Energy and Fisheries sectors in place; Draft National Wetlands Atlas in place. Draft Performance Measurement Framework (PMF) data collection tool in place and; Draft ENR gender strategy produced. 3. Electronic waste strategy in place. 4. Final Biomass Energy Strategy in place and launched. 5. Training manual on Climate Risk Management in place.

target.comment: 1. Monitoring, implementation framework and communication facility for the draft National Environment Management policy in place. 2. Final draft Wetlands Atlas in place. 3. Draft Electronic waste management guidelines in place.

actual.comment: 1. Draft monitoring, implementation framework and communication facility for the draft National Environment Management Policy (NEMP) in place. 2. Draft Wetlands Atlas in place. 3. Consultancy for developing Electronic waste management guidelines is ongoing.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Demonstration nurseries for trial and propagation of selected threatened tree species in place. 2. Acreage of degraded sites planted with threatened tree species 3. Number of target communities supported to develop eco-tourism strategies. 4. Number of community based organizations identified to pilot sustainable land management best practices. 5. Acreage of fragile environments/ dry lands planted with recommended trees. 6. Number institutional and household biogas units constructed. 7. Quantity of Renewable Energy Technologies (RET) produced/ adopted. 8. Number of innovative Climate change adaptation initiatives established

baseline.comment: 1. Zero or No demonstration nurseries for threatened tree species in biodiversity hot spots. 2. Fragile environments are degraded and bare. 3. No target communities supported to develop eco-tourism strategies. Some areas have eco-tourism potential but lack innovative products for ecotourism. 4. Communities not implementing SLM best practices. 5. Fragile and dry lands are bare with no recommended trees. 6. Low adoption of alternative energy technologies such as no institutional and household biogas units. 7. There are no and/or inadequate quantities of RET produced/ adopted within the target communities. 8. Zero or no innovative climate change adaptation initiatives in target communities.

target.comment: 1. Demonstration nurseries for at least four (4) species of conservation concern in place 2. 1000ha in both institutions and degraded sites planted with both tree species of conservation concern and non-conservation concern 3. At least three (3) community management strategies and plans for ecotourism management in place 4. At least three (3) community based Catchment management action plans implementing SLM interventions. 5. 1000ha of degraded fragile landscapes restored through planting of recommended trees 6. At least 6 biogas units constructed. 7. At least three efficient biomass energy technologies tested and four community groups plus two institutions using RET 8. Sub-surface rain water harvesting technologies exist in 4 target districts

actual.comment: 1. Two demonstration nurseries for trial and propagation of selected threatened tree species established including one in Kasese District and another in Mitooma Districts. 2. A total of 148 Ha of degraded sites planted with threatened tree species. These included a total of 75 Ha of degraded sites in Kasese namely Mobuku forest reserve, Bugoye and Kitholu sub counties where a total of 35,000 seedlings were planted, and a total of 50 Ha in Mitooma District including 42 Ha where 19000 seedlings were planted on the bare hills of Katenge, Kabira Primary School and Bubare Church of Uganda and the 8 Ha in Kiryabwanga sub country where about 8000 seedlings were planted. 3. Two Community Based Organizations supported under the Small Grants Scheme to promote eco-tourism initiatives including one to construct a viewing platform at the escarpment and another to make paper from elephant dung both in Rubirizi Districts near Queen Elizabeth National Park. 4. Nineteen Community Based Organizations Catchment management action plans in place/ under the Small Grants Scheme and are practicing sustainable land management best practices through tree planting, digging of trenches across the steep slopes in Districts of Kasese, Mitooma, Rubirizi, Bududa and Manafwa Districts. For instance, in Bududa District along the slopes of Mountain Elgon, 39.5 km of trenches have been constructed and use of mulch & cow dung manure adopted. 5. One hundred and twenty four Hectares of fragile and dry lands planted with recommended trees including 105 Ha with indigenous species and 19 Ha with exotic species. 6. Two institutional biogas units were constructed including one in Butiru Secondary School in Manafwa District and one in Karambi Secondary School in Kasese District. 10 household biogas units were constructed including 4 in Manafwa, 2 in Isingiro Districts and another 4 household biogas units in Bududa. 7. One hundred and eighty mud cook stoves were constructed and distributed by a total of 1

target.comment: 1. 1000ha in both institutions and degraded sites planted with both tree species of conservation concern and non conservation concern as well as 1000ha of degraded landscapes restored. 2. At least six efficient biomass energy technologies tested in four Districts plus one institutions using Renewable Energy Technologies (RET). 3. At least three (3) community groups promoting climate resilient development strategies.

actual.comment:
1. A total of 584.6 Ha were planted with trees and stabilized with vegetation cover under small grants.
A total of 405.6ha were planted under small grants [in Kasese district, 124ha in Kitholhu Sub-County, 55.8ha in Mobuku forest reserve plus 7ha on private land; and in Mitooma district, bare hills of Katenga (0.8ha), Kabira (2ha), Kiyanga (1ha), Kashenshero (3ha) and Kanyabwanga (0.5ha) plus Mitooma town council (1ha)]. On the other hand, establishment of demonstration apiaries in the districts of Kasese (1) and Rubirizi (1) was supported. In addition, two CFM groups in the districts of Kasese and Rubirizi, that is, MIFA and BUECA respectively were trained on modern Beekeeping.
In addition a total of 179ha of fragile ecosystems were stabilized with vegetation cover under small grants throughout the districts of Bududa, Rubirizi, Mitooma and Kasese districts. In addition, a total of 88.5km of trench and water bands were constructed and vegetation cover to stabilize them planted (Bududa district 60.5km, Mitooma district 2km and Kasese district 26km). 2. A total of 17 Renewable Energy Technologies were established including 2 institutional biogas facilities constructed in the schools of Karambi and Butiru in Kasese and Manafwa districts respectively and 15 domestic biogas units including eight (8) in Manafwa district by a CBO, Youth ending hunger; six (6) in Bududa district by Namasho women group; one (1) in Isingiro district by Conservation Effort for Community Development (CECOD) were constructed. In addition, six (6) domestic biogas units were constructed through two contractors four in Manafwa district by NABUTI Renewable Energy Construction Company (2 units) and Mbale Renewable Energy (2 units) and, two (2) in Isingiro district by Ankole private sector foundation.
3. More than eight (8) communities were supported to promote climate development strategies ranging from sub surface water harvesting technologies, water harvesting tanks, planting of coffee seedli

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
i. Number of individuals supported with knowledge and skills for evidence-based analytical research
ii. Procedures and institutional mechanism to plan and produce evidence-based analytical research in place
iii. No. of Evidence Based Studies completed to inform policy formulation and implementation
iv. No. of Evidence Based Studies disseminated to inform policy formulation and implementation

baseline.comment:
Insufficient individual, organization and institutional capacities exist for research at EDPR
Policy Makers and the general public not fully utilizing evidence based analytical studies to inform decision making and policy formulation and implementation processes
Limited and/or no dissemination of evidence-based analytical studies to policy makers and engagement of general public in research and policy making processes

target.comment:
i.Twenty (20) individuals from government and national research community equipped with knowledge and skills for evidence-based analytical research
ii. One (1) set of research procedures and institutional mechanisms to plan, produce and manage evidence-based analytical research in place that inform government strategic policy making priorities iii. Two (2) Evidence Based Studies completed to inform policy formulation and implementation

actual.comment:
(1) In partnership with UN-DESA,30 individuals from Government of Uganda were trained in mainstreaming sustainable development in national development strategies through Sustainable Development Modeling (SDM). The SDM integrates two models that is the Marquette for MDGs Simulations model (MAMS) that was used in the preparation of the Uganda Millennium Development Goal (MDG) report 2013 and the Osymoses model that analyses energy efficiency,
(2) A set of research procedures and institutional mechanisms to plan, produce and manage evidence-based analytical research is in place. This informs government strategic policy making priorities. Specifically, Government of Uganda adopted the MDG report 2013 and was used in the preparation of the budget for the F/Y 2014/2015.
(3) One evidence Based Study was completed and informed policy formulation and implementation. The project has also supported the Ministry of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (MFPED) in the preparation of the bi-annual Poverty Status Report launched in September 2014.

target.comment:
Targets 1.1 : At least 18 offfcers trained in Macro modelling and microeconomic analytical skills in key government ministries dealing in energy, land, water, environment and agriculture institutionalised by 2015 Ministries using the skills acquired to produce at least 2 flagship reports reflecting gender needs/situations by 2015
Targets 1.2 Intergovernmental negotiation meeting attended by August 2015. At least 2 UN General Assembly meetings in New York attended by October 2015.
Targets 1.3 : Procedure for conducting research and advocacy strategy in place and implemented by September 2015.
Targets 1.4: Established research review panel by March 2015 and hold bi-annual review meetings as scheduled
Targets 1.5 : Management Information System functional by October 2015
Targets 1.6 : Procured office equipment identified in needs assessment by March 2015
Target 1.8: Project staff provide technical input in the background papers and quality assurance to the following reports; Poverty Status Report 2015. Sustainable Land Management Study MDG Report 2015. Northern Uganda HDR 2015 Preparation of F/Y Budgets 2015/16
Target 2.1: Research agenda in place
Target 2.2: At least 2 analytical papers produced with cross cutting issues on gender, HIV/AIDS, youths to influence policy dialogue and advocacy by November 2015
Target 2.3: Flagship reports produced by 2015 i.e., 2015 Poverty Status Report National Human Development Report 2015 Strategies for the sustainable land use and management. 2015 Uganda MDG Report Cross cutting issues on gender and youths integrated in the reports
Target 3.1:Web portal created and accessible to all stakeholders by September 2015.
Target 3.2: At least 2 policy dialogues organized

actual.comment:
The following results have been achieved as of May 2015
Output 1.1 -21 officers completed the second training in energy systems modeling under the Sustainable Development Modeling component done in collaboration with UNDESA. -Completed the development of course materials for the micro-economic analysis using STATA for in house training.
Output 1.8 Project staff have offered technical input and quality assurance to the following research products -Inception reports for the Sustainable Land Management Report and National Human Development Report for Northern Uganda 2015. - Write up on the sectoral performance _Chapter 6 of the BTTB 2015/16.
Output 2.3 -Completed background papers for the National Human Development Report for Northern Uganda 2015. -Completed concept note for the national MDG Report 2015. -Dissemination of the Poverty Status Report 2014 completed in Western and Central Regions. -Completed Mini PPA study design on the implications of instituting a statutory minimum wage on informal and formal businesses in Uganda. -Completed the State of Nation Enterprise Report which will form a chapter in the Private Sector Development Report planned for FY 2015/16 .

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: i) Number of staff trained in aid coordination, project management and quality assurance ii) Functional Monitoring mechanism for aid coordination and management in place iii) Number of donor funded project monitoring reports iv) CPAP midterm/annual review reports

baseline.comment: 1. No /Insufficient staff skills for Aid Coordination, Result based project implementation and Quality Assurance Inadequate knowledge of best practices to coordinate aid 2. No functional Monitoring mechanism for aid coordination and management in place. Poor reporting and accountability due to weak monitoring and Evaluation systems in place. Inadequate and malfunctioning equipment in place. 3. No Monitoring reports; 4. No programme reviews/evaluations

target.comment: 1.20 staff trained in aid coordination, project management and quality assurance. Build skills of Aid Liaison Department (ALD) staff in Overseas Development Aid (ODA) management through training basing on the Training Needs assessment report. 2. Functional Monitoring mechanism for aid coordination and management in place.Development partner data reconciled for annual ODA reporting 3. Project reports ( audit; annual/portfolio review) in place and action Plan in place. At least 5 international and 3 local events on ODA best practices supported and at least one best practice applied for ODA management 4. UNDAF Review conducted, recommendations shared. Annual CPAP evaluation conducted, recommendations shared

Output 1: Current knowledge and best practices on ODA coordination attained and applied
1. 20 staff trained in ODA management related courses; At least 4 international and 3 local ODA events supported and one best practice implemented 2. Development partner data reconciled for annual ODA reporting
3.Report on impact of Aid finalized and disseminated
Output 2: CO Programme oversight and management successfully undertaken in line with UNDPs policies and procedures. 1. UNDAF Review report in place and recommendations 2. Country Programme Document 2015-2020 approved by government 3. New projects micro-assessed and IPs trained in UNDP policies and procedures. 4. 2015 UNDAF Review conducted;

actual.comment:
Output 1: 1. In 2015 8 people (2 female and 6 male) were sponsored by UNDP for capacity building trainings and 6 people (4 females and 2 males) were supported to attend ODA and climate change mitigation meetings and workshops, bringing the cumulative number of those supported through training to 60 people Ministry staff. 10 UNDP staff were also supported for training. The governments participation in several post Busan meetings culminated in the country successfully hosting the 2015 Development Cooperation Forum in November. Continued participation in the UNFCCC COP meetings has resulted in enhancing the Governments external resource mobilisation through access to the Global Environment Facility (GEF), with Uganda getting an allocation of $14m for 2015-2018., and the Green Climate Fund (GCF), to which MoFPED has recently finalised and presented to GCF a readiness proposal for $300,000. 2. The monitoring and evaluation mechanism for aid coordination and management has been enhance through the regularizing of annual country portfolio reviews for UNDP development projects. This has provided an avenue for project implementation review, resolution of issues by government and UNDP. This, in conjunction with periodic follow up has improved portfolio delivery and performance for both UNDP and other development projects. Increased monitoring by MoFPED has resulted in reduced audit queries on Government projects, reduced commitment fees payable on undisbursed donor loan funds and improved quality of ODA reporting. 3. Quality of the Report on Loans, Grants and Guarantees to Parliament for the recent financial years has improved and expanded to include project support, technical assistance and off-budget support, in addition to the traditional budget support.
Output 2: 1. The UNDP country office supported review of the 2010-2015 United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF), which helped to inform the formulation of the 2016-2020 UNDAF which was launched in June

indicator.description: Number of institutions integrating environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans; (Disaggregated by level i.e National/Local government

baseline.comment: No and/or Ineffectual institutional capacity for selected national institutions and Local Governments to review, develop and implement policies/strategies for ENRM/CC adaptation, mitigation and DRR in place (2010

target.comment: -20 institutions integrate environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans; -Established institutions and processes for early warning, disaster and climate modelling, assessments and emergency/recovery coordination. - Conduct nationwide comprehensive hazard, risk, and Vulnerability mapping/profiling - Pilot of innovative approaches on Disaster and climate risk and resilience-building - Improved preparedness level and response to early recovery needs. - Improved capacities and harmonized tools/approaches for more efficient delivery of Disaster /Climate Risk Management initiatives - capacity at national and sub national levels in place to manage disaster and climate risk management

actual.comment: - 25 institutions integrated environment, Climate Change, DRR and energy access in development plans -Existence of established and operationalized institutions and process for early warning, disaster and climate modelling, assessments and emergency/recovery coordination. - Nationwide comprehensive hazard, risk, and Vulnerability mapping/profiling completed - Innovative approaches on Disaster and climate risk and resilience-building piloted - Existence of an institution for Improved preparedness level and response to early recovery needs. - Harmonized tools/approaches in place for more efficient delivery of Disaster /Climate Risk Management initiatives - Capacity at national and sub national levels to manage disaster and climate risk management in place

target.comment: - Develop the Strategic Programmes and Investment Framework document - Strengthen co-ordination of DRR activities through the conduct and facilitation of regular National Platform for DRR meetings. -Operationalize and roll out the Early Warning systems in targeted districts in Teso, Acholi and West Nile sub regions. - Conduct national Hazard Risk and Vulnerability assessment for targeted districts and publish their hazard profiles. - Commemorate the observance of special days/events including the International day for DRR.

actual.comment: i) Strengthened national DRR institutions, enhanced sectoral coordination and DRR main-streamed into national and sector-specific development policies and programmes ii. Evidence base for DRR generated and post-disaster recovery strengthened iii. Enhanced community resilience to disasters iv. Enhanced capacity for comprehensive disaster risk reduction

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. National Consultative Forum (NCF) fully operational with key capacities to deliver on constitutional mandate
2.Existence of legislation associated with electoral processes and multiparty political dispensation
3. Operational Non-state dialogue platform in place i.e policy and governance settlements facilitated by the National Elders Forum (NEF) and Operational framework for NEF finalized
4. Policy and governance settlements facilitated by Non-structures (NEF and in close conjunction with NCF and IRCU)
5. Regional peace and conflict transformation forums in place- led dialogue and internal mediation in diffusing conflict triggers at regional levels
6. Existence of Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF/NCF/IRCU.

baseline.comment:
1. Forum for dialogue with constitutional mandate exists with limited information on capacity needs of forum
2. Political reform dialogue towards strengthening multiparty political dispensation within NCF not yet fully developed. Core Electoral reform proposals already developed/identified. NCF support for approval through next steps of legislative processes needed.
3. Non-state dialogue platform not fully operationalized
4. Limited non-state structures that can facilitate dialogue and consensus building
5. Regional level peace-building infrastructure is weak and limited in capacity
6. Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF is not in existence.

target.comment:
1. National Consultative Forum (NCF) fully operational with key capacities to deliver on constitutional mandate
2. Existence of legislation associated with electoral processes and multiparty political dispensation finalized
3. Operational Non-state dialogue platform in place i.e policy and governance settlements facilitated by the NEF Operational framework for National Elders Forum (NEF) finalized 4. Policy and governance settlements are facilitated by Non-structures 5.Regional peace and conflict transformation forums in place- led dialogue and internal mediation in diffusing conflict triggers at regional levels 6. Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF/NCF/IRCU in place

actual.comment:
1. National Consultative Forum (NCF) fully operational with key capacities to deliver on constitutional mandate
2. Existence of legislation associated with electoral processes and multiparty political dispensation finalized
3. Operational Non-state dialogue platform in place i.e policy and governance settlements facilitated by the NEF Operational framework for National Elders Forum (NEF) finalized 4. Policy and governance settlements are facilitated by Non-structures (NEF and in close conjunction with NCF and Inter religious Council Of Uganda (IRCU) 5. Regional peace and conflict transformation forums in place- led dialogue and internal mediation in diffusing conflict triggers at regional levels 6.Existence of Independent and impartial secretariat for the operations of the NEF/NCF/IRCU.

target.comment:
Output 1 1. 17 electoral reform proposals finalized and cleared by cabinet for 2016 elections 2. political dialogue meetings internally within NCF and with key policy and political establishments held 3. Partnerships with key national institutions strengthened
Output 2 1. 32 members of NCF (representatives of political parties) trained in dialogue, mediation and negotiation skills 2. Guidelines for NCF role as consensus builder, analyst of political trends, conflict resolver and convener developed 3. Internal capacities of NCF through simulation exercises on political dialogue strengthened. 4. Dedicated web site for NCF developed 5. 2 sensitization workshops held in West Nile region and Albertine region
Output 3 1. National Elders Forum fully functional and operational Launched 2. Regular meetings of the NEF organized 3. Strategic partnerships and engagements developed 4. Internal dialogue on key topical issues impacting peace and stability facilitated
Output 4 1. Policy and governance reform dialogue processes in partnership with NCF and IRCU facilitated and finalized 2. Capacity of Women in Faith Network to coordinate religious action for women's role in peace-building strengthened
Outtput 5 1. 4 regional peace and conflict transformation forums established 2. Early warning tool to monitor developments that impact peace and stability integrated 3. Peace and conflict transformation Forums to facilitate dialogue interventions identified 4. Services of a full time focal point for managing the early warning tool within IRCU recruited
Output 6 1. fully functional secretariat to support NEF operations and project management in place

actual.comment: 1 regional NCF sensitization workshop in the West Nile region (Arua) on the NCF Operations was conducted with attendance of 224 participants benefiting in the workshop.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1. Existence of a new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) 2. Number of selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced i.e.
3. Existence of Spatial mapping report and associated maps 4. Existence of NDPII incorrporating an M&E framework.

baseline.comment:
1. No new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) . Only NDPI exists; 2. No NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced yet.
3. No existence of Spatial mapping report and associated maps 4. None existence of NDPII incorporating an M&E framework.

target.comment:
1. A new macroeconomic framework for National Development Plan (NDP-II) in place 2. Five selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced
3. Spatial mapping report and associated maps in place 4. Existence of NDPII incorporating an M&E framework.

actual.comment:
1. A New macroeconomic framework for NDP-II was developed 2. Six selected NDP-II Cross-cutting Theme Papers produced i.e. a. NDP-II cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Democratic governance and the NDP-II completed b. NDP-II cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Sustainability, environmental management and the NDP-II completed c. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of Mainstreaming Non-State Actors participation in the NDP completed d. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of youth in the NDP completed e. NDP-II Cross-cutting theme paper on the topic of agriculture and land main streaming in the NDP completed f. NDP-II LG Issues papers completed. 4. Spatial mapping report and associated maps completed 5. NDPII completed incorporating an M&E framework
1.1 Macro framework draft has been finalized and will be presented to cabinet and Parliament for review and approval. 1.2 The Core macro team from NPA was trained in development strategies through Sustainable Development Modeling (SDM). The SDM integrates two models that is the Marquette for MDGs Simulations model that was used in the preparation of the Uganda MDG report 2013 and the Osymoses model that analyses energy efficiency, as well as other enabling factors such as land, agriculture and the environment which will come in handy given the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals.

target.comment: 1. Provide technical Backstopping of Local Gorvenments and Municipalities in developing their development plans 2. Ensure Quality Assurance of Local Government Development Plans 3. Provide Project management support

actual.comment: National Planning Authority has so far trained over 30 Local Governments on the use of the LG development planning guidelines and supported them in developing their plans. This activity is expected to end in the last week of June. NPA will start providing Quality Assurance in July 2015.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1 Number of hectares of land under CSA practices in the 5 districts 2 Number of schools in the 5 district integrate CSA in their gardens 3 Number of private sector input actors participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 4 Number of input credit system established per district 5 Number of artisans trained in production of CSA tools 6 Number of producer associations identified, trained and supported to establish SACCOs 7 Lessons on CSA documented 8 Number of CSA technologies for which trials are carried out 9 Number of publication of findings and recommendations

baseline.comment: 1. 2,500 hectares of land under Climate Smart Agriculture practices in target districts 2 No school in the 5 districts integrate CSA 3 1 private sector input actor (Uganda National Agro Inputs Dealers Association) participate in supply of quality inputs on market 4 No input credit system established per district 5 1 artisan (TONNET Enterprise Limited) trained in production of CSA tools 6 No Producer Associations identified, trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Associations. 7 No lessons on CSA documented and disseminated. Limited knowledge management, no clear mechanism for generating and sharing lessons. 8 No trials for CSA technologies carried out 9 No publication of findings and recommendations

target.comment: 1 At least 15,000 hectares put under CSA practices in 5 districts. 2 At least 20 schools in the 5 districts integrate CSA in their gardens. 3 At least 15 private sector actors participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 4 At least one input credit system established per district. 5 At least 10 artisans trained in production of CSA tools. 6 At least 10 producer associations identified, trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Organisations (SACCOs). 7 Lessons on CSA documented and available for dissemination. 8 Trials on at least four (4) CSA technologies carried out. 9 At least 2 publications of findings and recommendations.

actual.comment: 1 14 hectares (1 Ha per school for 14 schools) put under CSA practices in 5 districts 2 14 schools in the 5 districts integrate CSA in their gardens. 3 6 private sector actors supply quality inputs for CSA upscaling. 4 No input credit system established in the districts 5 10 artisans were identified for production of CSA tools, 6 Five (5) producer associations supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Organizations (SACCOs) 7 Lessons on CSA were neither documented nor made available for disseminated in the year 8 Field Trials on any CSA technologies were not carried out because of bad weather 9 Publications of findings and recommendations were not done because not enough data had been generated

target.comment: 1. At least 10,000 hectares put under CSA practices in 5 districts 2. At least 30 schools in the 5 districts integrate CSA in their gardens. 3. 3,500 farmers practice CSA in the five targeted districts of Bugiri, Busia, Budaka, Namutumba and Buyende. 4. Capacity of Stakeholders in Particular Extension Staff, Farmer - Trainers Of Trainers and School Teachers Developed to Extend CSA Technologies. 5. Mechanization of Conservation agriculture practices done with 200 sets of rippers methodology developed to monitor impact of CSA practices among farmers in the 5 districts 6. At least 15 private sector actors participate in the supply of quality inputs on market. 7. At least 10 artisans trained in production of CSA tools. 8. At least 10 producer associations identified and trained and supported to establish Savings and Credit Cooperative Organisations (SACCOs) 9. Capacity of members of at least 10 producer associations built to do effective post harvest handling of crop

actual.comment: 1. 800 ha was put under CSA practices in the 5 districts 2. 30 schools integrated CSA in their school gardens, particularly conservation agriculture including use of permanent planting basins and mulching for minimum tillage, soil and water conservation structures, early planting and use of improved quality seeds. This activity included 250 girls, 350 boys in the 5 districts. 3. A total of 2500 farmers including 1378 women, 561 men in the five districts practiced CSA using maize and beans as major crops produced. 4. At least 320 farmers and farmer trainers were trained including 115 females. 5. 200 sets of rippers were distributed to 30 groups of farmers which lead to doubling of land put under Conservation agriculture during one season.. 6. At least 20 private sector actors participated in the 5 district level platforms set up for interaction between service providers/input suppliers. 7. Ten(10) local artisans were trained in fabrication of tools including single rippers, and were equipped with tool boxes and start up kits. 8. Ten (100 producer association were identified and trained on formation of primary cooperatives, 3 have registered their associations and 7 are at different levels in the process of development and registration as cooperatives. 9. Members of the 10 producer associations were trained on post harvest handling of crop and facilitated to acquire at least 100 Pardue Improved Crop storage bags each.
